_[Family Guy](/wiki/Family_Guy "Family Guy")_ 's third season first aired on
the [Fox](/wiki/Fox_Broadcasting_Company "Fox Broadcasting Company") network
in 22 episodes from July 11, 2001, to November 9, 2003, before being released
as a DVD box set and in syndication. It premiered with the episode "[The Thin
White Line](/wiki/The_Thin_White_Line "The Thin White Line")" and finished
with "[When You Wish Upon a Weinstein](/wiki/When_You_Wish_Upon_a_Weinstein
"When You Wish Upon a Weinstein")". The third season of _[Family
Guy](/wiki/Family_Guy "Family Guy")_ continues the adventures of the
dysfunctional [Griffin family](/wiki/Griffin_family "Griffin family")—father
[Peter](/wiki/Peter_Griffin "Peter Griffin"), mother [Lois](/wiki/Lois_Griffin
"Lois Griffin"), daughter [Meg](/wiki/Meg_Griffin "Meg Griffin"), son
[Chris](/wiki/Chris_Griffin "Chris Griffin"), baby
[Stewie](/wiki/Stewie_Griffin "Stewie Griffin") and
[Brian](/wiki/Brian_Griffin "Brian Griffin"), the family pet, who reside in
their hometown of [Quahog](/wiki/Quahog_\(Family_Guy\) "Quahog \(Family
Guy\)").

The [executive producers](/wiki/Executive_producer "Executive producer") for
the third production season were [Dan Palladino](/wiki/Daniel_Palladino
"Daniel Palladino") and series creator [Seth MacFarlane](/wiki/Seth_MacFarlane
"Seth MacFarlane"). The aired season also contained nine episodes which were
holdovers from season two, which were produced by MacFarlane and [David
Zuckerman](/wiki/David_Zuckerman "David Zuckerman").

Although _Family Guy_ was initially canceled in 2000 due to low
[ratings](/wiki/Nielsen_ratings "Nielsen ratings"), following a last-minute
reprieve, the series returned for a third season in 2001. The series was
canceled again in 2002; however, high ratings on [Adult Swim](/wiki/Adult_Swim
"Adult Swim") and high DVD sales renewed Fox's interest in the series. The
series returned for a total of 35 new episodes in 2005.

##
Production[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Family_Guy_\(season_3\)&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Production")]

[![A Caucasian male with black hair and stubble, along with a black shirt. His
hand is placed under his chin and a microphone is in front of him. A vague
simple is marked behind
him.](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/Seth_MacFarlane_by_Gage_Skidmore_5.jpg/155px-
Seth_MacFarlane_by_Gage_Skidmore_5.jpg)](/wiki/File:Seth_MacFarlane_by_Gage_Skidmore_5.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Seth_MacFarlane_by_Gage_Skidmore_5.jpg "Enlarge")

[Seth MacFarlane](/wiki/Seth_MacFarlane "Seth MacFarlane") was nominated for
an [Emmy Award](/wiki/Emmy_Award "Emmy Award") for Best Song for the episode
"[Brian Wallows and Peter's
Swallows](/wiki/Brian_Wallows_and_Peter%27s_Swallows "Brian Wallows and
Peter's Swallows")"

_Family Guy_ was first canceled in 2000 following the series' [second
season](/wiki/Family_Guy_\(season_2\) "Family Guy \(season 2\)"), but
following a last-minute reprieve, it returned for a third season in 2001.[1]
In 2002, the series was canceled again after three seasons due to low
[ratings](/wiki/Nielsen_ratings "Nielsen ratings").[2][3][4][5] Fox attempted
to sell the rights for reruns of the show, but it was difficult to find
networks that were interested; [Cartoon Network](/wiki/Cartoon_Network
"Cartoon Network") eventually bought the rights, "[...] basically for free",
according to the president of 20th Century Fox Television Production.[6]

When the reruns were shown on Cartoon Network's [Adult Swim](/wiki/Adult_Swim
"Adult Swim") in 2003, _Family Guy_ became Adult Swim's most-watched show with
an average 1.9 million viewers an episode.[7] Following _Family Guy_ 's high
ratings on Adult Swim, the first season was released on DVD in April 2003.[2]
Sales of the DVD set reached 2.2 million copies,[8] becoming the best-selling
television DVD of 2003[9] and the second highest-selling television DVD ever,
behind the first season of [Comedy Central](/wiki/Comedy_Central "Comedy
Central")'s _[Chappelle's Show](/wiki/Chappelle%27s_Show "Chappelle's
Show")_.[10] The second season DVD release also sold more than a million
copies.[7] The show's popularity in both DVD sales and reruns rekindled Fox's
interest in it.[11] They ordered 35 new episodes in 2004, marking the first
revival of a television show based on DVD sales.[10][12] Fox president [Gail
Berman](/wiki/Gail_Berman "Gail Berman") said that it was one of her most
difficult decisions to cancel the show, and was therefore happy it would
return.[6] The network also began production of a film based on the series.[9]

[Dan Povenmire](/wiki/Dan_Povenmire "Dan Povenmire"), who became a director on
_[Family Guy](/wiki/Family_Guy "Family Guy")_ during the series' second
season,[13] took a more prominent role in directing by the third season,
having directed five episodes. Creator [Seth MacFarlane](/wiki/Seth_MacFarlane
"Seth MacFarlane") granted Povenmire substantial creative freedom. Povenmire
recalled that MacFarlane would tell him "We've got two minutes to fill. Give
me some visual gags. Do whatever you want. I trust you." Povenmire praised
this management style for letting him "have [...] fun." Povenmire brought
realism, and material from his own experiences, to the visual direction of
_Family Guy_.[14][15] For "[One If by Clam, Two If by
Sea](/wiki/One_If_by_Clam,_Two_If_by_Sea "One If by Clam, Two If by
Sea")",[16] several characters carried out fosse moves in prison — Povenmire
went into the office of a color artist, Cynthia Macintosh, who had been a
professional dancer, and had her strike poses in order for him to better
illustrate the sequence.[15] In the episode "[To Love and Die in
Dixie](/wiki/To_Love_and_Die_in_Dixie "To Love and Die in Dixie")"[17]
Povenmire drew on his childhood in the deep south to sequence a background
scene where the "[redneck](/wiki/Redneck "Redneck")" character nonchalantly
kicks a [corpse](/wiki/Corpse "Corpse") into the nearby [river](/wiki/River
"River").[14]

##
Reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Family_Guy_\(season_3\)&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Reception")]

The episode [Brian Wallows and Peter's
Swallows](/wiki/Brian_Wallows_and_Peter%27s_Swallows "Brian Wallows and
Peter's Swallows") won an [Emmy Award](/wiki/Emmy_Award "Emmy Award") for Best
Song. Creator MacFarlane, the recipient of the award, noted that the episode's
director Dan Povenmire[18] deserved to have received the award for the
contribution the visuals made to the episode's win. Povenmire jokingly
responded "That's a nice sentiment and all, but did he offer to give me his?
No! And it's not like he doesn't already have two of his own just sitting in
his house!"[19]

The third season has received positive reviews from critics. In his review for
the _Family Guy_ Volume 3 DVD, Aaron Beierle of [DVD Talk](/wiki/DVD_Talk "DVD
Talk") stated "Often brilliant, extremely witty and darkly hilarious, _Family
Guy_ was unfortunately cancelled after Fox bumped it around six or seven
different time slots. Although this third season wasn't as consistent as the
first two, it's still hilarious and fans of the show should definitely pick up
this terrific set."[20]

29 | 1 | "[The Thin White Line](/wiki/The_Thin_White_Line "The Thin White Line")" | Glen Hill | [Steve Callaghan](/wiki/Steve_Callaghan "Steve Callaghan") | July 11, 2001 (2001-07-11) | 2ACX17  
Peter wins the [Griffin family](/wiki/Griffin_family "Griffin family") a
cruise after winning a company competition. Shortly before the family prepares
to leave, Joe recognizes the sensitivity of Brian's nose and offers him a job
detecting drugs as a police [sniffer dog](/wiki/Sniffer_dog "Sniffer dog"). At
the airport, Brian uncovers a bystander carrying [cocaine](/wiki/Cocaine
"Cocaine"); however, he accidentally inhales it. The next morning, Brian has
an emotional breakdown after the family stages an intervention with his
psychiatrist. The family compromises on sending him to
[rehab](/wiki/Substance-abuse_rehabilitation "Substance-abuse rehabilitation")
with their vacation money. Peter joins Brian since he now cannot go on
vacation, and the two cause unrest among their fellow patients by causing
premature births in pregnant teens. After the two are caught, Peter is accused
of being Brian's "x-factor"; however, Brian manages to defend him and decides
to leave the center. The Griffins throw a party to celebrate Brian's return,
but are shocked when he announces that he is leaving Quahog to [Los
Angeles](/wiki/Los_Angeles "Los Angeles") to continue the search for the
thrill of his life.  
30 | 2 | "[Brian Does Hollywood](/wiki/Brian_Does_Hollywood "Brian Does Hollywood")" | Gavin Dell | [Gary Janetti](/wiki/Gary_Janetti "Gary Janetti") | July 18, 2001 (2001-07-18) | 2ACX20  
Brian moves to [Los Angeles](/wiki/Los_Angeles "Los Angeles") with his cousin
[Jasper](/wiki/List_of_characters_from_Family_Guy#Brian.27s_family "List of
characters from Family Guy") after his drug rehabilitation and inadvertently
becomes a film director. The family decides to visit Brian for support in his
new career; however, when it turns out Brian is directing
[pornography](/wiki/Pornography "Pornography"), he attempts to keep it a
secret from the family. Meanwhile, Stewie auditions for _[Kids Say the
Darndest Things](/wiki/Kids_Say_the_Darndest_Things "Kids Say the Darndest
Things")_ in order to unleash a [mass hypnosis](/wiki/Mass_hypnosis "Mass
hypnosis"); however, during the show the following night, host [Bill
Cosby](/wiki/Bill_Cosby "Bill Cosby") grabs Stewie's device and unwittingly
foils his plan. Elsewhere, Brian is nominated for Best Director at the [Woody
Awards](/wiki/Academy_Awards "Academy Awards") for adult films; Jasper informs
the Griffin family about Brian's job and attend the awards, much to Brian's
relief. By the end of the episode, he decides to return to Quahog with his
family.  
31 | 3 | "[Mr. Griffin Goes to Washington](/wiki/Mr._Griffin_Goes_to_Washington "Mr. Griffin Goes to Washington")" | Brian Hogan | [Ricky Blitt](/wiki/Ricky_Blitt "Ricky Blitt") | July 25, 2001 (2001-07-25) | 2ACX11  
The Happy-Go-Lucky Toy Factory is purchased by a tobacco conglomerate. Lois
develops concern for Peter and believes the company is promoting underage
smoking; Peter attempts to confront management, but is distractingly appointed
president in the process; the family is pampered and treated elegantly as a
result. At a meeting, the company decides to send Peter to [Washington,
D.C.](/wiki/Washington,_D.C. "Washington, D.C.") in order to prevent a new
anti-smoking bill from being passed into
[Congress](/wiki/United_States_Congress "United States Congress"). is to send
someone just as dumb, and they decide to send Peter. At home, Lois catches
Stewie smoking and attempts to take the family to the meeting in Washington;
although Peter prepares to deliver his speech on the floors of Congress
assembled, he spots Stewie coughing from smoking and tells Congress to reject
El Dorado's proposal. When they agree, El Dorado is fined as a result, driving
the company to bankruptcy.  
32 | 4 | "[One If by Clam, Two If by Sea](/wiki/One_If_by_Clam,_Two_If_by_Sea "One If by Clam, Two If by Sea")" | [Dan Povenmire](/wiki/Dan_Povenmire "Dan Povenmire") | [Jim Bernstein](/wiki/Jim_Bernstein "Jim Bernstein") & [Michael Shipley](/wiki/Michael_Shipley_\(writer\) "Michael Shipley \(writer\)") | August 1, 2001 (2001-08-01) | 2ACX19  
A hurricane demolishes the majority of the buildings in Quahog —except the
Drunken Clam; however, the bar's owner leaves for Florida sells it to an
[Englishman](/wiki/Englishman "Englishman") named Nigel Pinchley, who turns it
into a [British](/wiki/British_people "British people")
[stereotypical](/wiki/Stereotypical "Stereotypical") pub. Upset over the loss
of their favorite bar and failing to find another one, Peter, Quagmire,
Cleveland, and Joe storm a British ship in an attempt to recreate the [Boston
Tea Party](/wiki/Boston_Tea_Party "Boston Tea Party") with beer. The following
night, the pub burns down; Peter, Quagmire, Cleveland, and Joe are blamed and
thrown in jail. In prison, one of the toughest criminals Joe ever jailed,
Steve Bellows, plans to kill him and the others at midnight on Saturday.
Meanwhile, Stewie tries to teach Nigel's daughter, Eliza to speak "proper"
[English](/wiki/English_language "English language") and overcome her "common"
[Cockney](/wiki/Cockney "Cockney") accent as part of a bet with Brian;
although he manages to teach her how to speak "properly", at the party, she
urinates in front of everybody, slipping back to her Cockney accent and making
Stewie lose the bet. Lois, Bonnie, and Loretta decide to investigate the bar's
destruction, and discover that Nigel had withdrawn a large amount of insurance
money the day before the pub burned down, they become suspicious. Lois seduces
Nigel into confessing, and his insurance agent discovers the entire story. In
jail, Peter, Quagmire, Cleveland, and Joe are rescued before Steve has a
chance to kill them, and the Drunken Clam is reinstated to its normal form. In
[London](/wiki/London "London"), Nigel is hanged and Eliza is sent to an
orphanage.

Peter is intimidated by Chris' larger [penis](/wiki/Penis "Penis") and then
becomes very self-conscious about his own manhood, joining a gun club to make
himself feel more masculine. Peter decides to take Chris on a hunting trip
with his new gun, where the two are attacked by a bear; Chris manages to save
both of them by making loud noises and jumping in front of the bear. Peter
apologizes to Chris and realizes that being a man is about bravery and not
size. Meanwhile, Meg tries out for cheerleading but is accepted into the [flag

squad instead, where she is pelted with rancid meat by several of the more
popular children in her school. The next day, Lois instructs Meg to make
friends with Connie D'Amico and prank her whenever the time his right.
However, the plan fails when the popular kids trick Meg at Connie's sixteenth
birthday, where they trick her into kissing pig she thought was a popular boy.
However, Lois and Meg have the last laugh when the former sends Quagmire to
molest the teenagers.  
34 | 6 | "[Death Lives](/wiki/Death_Lives "Death Lives")" | [Rob Renzetti](/wiki/Rob_Renzetti "Rob Renzetti") | [Mike Henry](/wiki/Mike_Henry_\(voice_actor\) "Mike Henry \(voice actor\)") | August 15, 2001 (2001-08-15) | 2ACX21  
On their wedding anniversary, Peter sends Lois all over Quahog on a scavenger
hunt so he can go play golf. But when Peter gets struck by lightning and has a
near-death experience, he meets Death again, who explains to Peter his
marriage is in trouble if he does not have a revelation, and fast.  
35 | 7 | "[Lethal Weapons](/wiki/Lethal_Weapons "Lethal Weapons")" | Brian Hogan | [Chris Sheridan](/wiki/Chris_Sheridan_\(writer\) "Chris Sheridan \(writer\)") | August 22, 2001 (2001-08-22) | 2ACX18  
Lois takes taijutsu lessons to fight back against the leafers (New York
tourists) overtaking the town, but worries that her violence may be a bad
influence on her family. When [anger management](/wiki/Anger_management "Anger

brawl to get it out of their system.  
36 | 8 | "[The Kiss Seen Around the World](/wiki/The_Kiss_Seen_Around_the_World "The Kiss Seen Around the World")" | [Pete Michels](/wiki/Pete_Michels "Pete Michels") | [Mark Hentemann](/wiki/Mark_Hentemann "Mark Hentemann") | August 29, 2001 (2001-08-29) | 3ACX02  
Meg applies for an internship at Quahog 5 (due to her crush on news anchor
[Tom Tucker](/wiki/Tom_Tucker_\(Family_Guy\) "Tom Tucker \(Family Guy\)")),

37 | 9 | "[Mr. Saturday Knight](/wiki/Mr._Saturday_Knight "Mr. Saturday Knight")" | [Michael Dante DiMartino](/wiki/Michael_Dante_DiMartino "Michael Dante DiMartino") | Steve Callaghan | September 5, 2001 (2001-09-05) | 3ACX04  
Peter's boss, Mr. Weed, dies during a dinner with the Griffin family, and the

38 | 10 | "[A Fish Out of Water](/wiki/A_Fish_out_of_Water_\(Family_Guy\) "A Fish out of Water \(Family Guy\)")" | Bert Ring | [Alex Borstein](/wiki/Alex_Borstein "Alex Borstein") & Mike Henry | September 19, 2001 (2001-09-19) | 3ACX05

a fisherman, but faces problems when he has to pay off a boat loan, so he
tries to catch the bounty for a legendary fish. Meanwhile, Lois takes Meg to
the beach for spring break, but Lois ends up having more fun than Meg.  
39 | 11 | "[Emission Impossible](/wiki/Emission_Impossible "Emission Impossible")" | [Peter Shin](/wiki/Peter_Shin "Peter Shin") | Dave Collard & Ken Goin | November 8, 2001 (2001-11-08) | 3ACX01

45 | 17 | "[Brian Wallows and Peter's Swallows](/wiki/Brian_Wallows_and_Peter%27s_Swallows "Brian Wallows and Peter's Swallows")" | Dan Povenmire | [Allison Adler](/wiki/Allison_Adler "Allison Adler") | January 17, 2002 (2002-01-17) | 3ACX03

46 | 18 | "[From Method to Madness](/wiki/From_Method_to_Madness "From Method to Madness")" | Bert Ring | Mike Barker & Matt Weitzman | January 24, 2002 (2002-01-24) | 3ACX11

Michael Shipley & Jim Bernstein | February 14, 2002 (2002-02-14) | 3ACX12  
Brian and Stewie host a special episode of _Family Guy_ , featuring three non-
canon stories created from viewer requests.  
**No Bones About It** – A genie comes to Peter to grant him wishes; his last
wish makes it so that he has no bones and must deal with life as a lump of
lard.  
**Supergriffins** – The Griffins are exposed to nuclear waste and gain
superpowers, which lead them to terrorize the city.  
**Li 'l Griffins** – Tot-like versions of Peter and Quagmire try to out-brave
each other in a haunted house to impress Lois in this _[Little
Rascals](/wiki/Little_Rascals "Little Rascals")_ parody.  
50 | 22 | "[When You Wish Upon a Weinstein](/wiki/When_You_Wish_Upon_a_Weinstein "When You Wish Upon a Weinstein")" | Dan Povenmire | Ricky Blitt | November 9, 2003 (2003-11-09) (on [Adult Swim](/wiki/Adult_Swim "Adult Swim"))  
December 10, 2004 (on Fox) | 2ACX05  
Peter prays for a [Jew](/wiki/Jews "Jews") to help him with his money woes.
After befriending a Jewish accountant, Max Weinstein, and discovering the
wonders of their religion, Peter gets the ridiculous idea of converting Chris
to Judaism as soon as possible so he will be successful in life, but Lois
tries to stop him, claiming that success is not based on religion.
